utterances: Hey, I'm a scientist.
I like being accurate.
So how do you do this calculation then?
Well, then you have to know how many people there are on Earth.
And I found that there were...
Six and a half billion...
People as of midnight on December 31, 2005.
OK.
So now all she has to do is divide her trees by people.
But before you did that, did you have any sense of the outcome of how this was...
No, I had no idea whether there was, like, one tree per person or whether there would be a thousand trees per people.
Have you had any hopes or some gut feeling?
You know, I severely hoped that there was more than one tree per person, but I feared and thought that there would be fewer trees than people.
You know, because...
I'm trying to think what I - I thought there would be like - I always - I thought there'd be a hundred trees per person.
Interesting.
But when she did the calculation.
So what's the...
The magic number turns out to be 61 per person.
Sixty-one trees per person.
That's a pretty big number.
Yes.
I said, hooray!
I get more than one tree.
I'm in a sort of silly way.
But I thought that's a lot of trees.
You know, that means every person walking through Times Square, you know, has 61 trees.
That's so fantastic.
But then I talked to my husband about it, you know, at the breakfast table.
And I said, Jack, we get 61 trees apiece.
That's huge.
And he looked at me in his quiet, sort of slow way and said, well, you know, I don't know.
We use about that much in a couple of seasons of, you know, our wood stove and the lumber that made our home.
So maybe it's not so many.
And I've been struggling with that thought ever since.
It's like, is it a lot or a little?
I'm not sure.
Because we all know there's lumber in our homes and furniture and toothpicks.
But then you get into things like golf balls.
Whose bounce comes from the gum of the gutta-percha tree.
Or the number of disposable chopsticks in Japan every year.
Over 20 billion pairs.
That's 40 billion chopsticks thrown away every year, says Professor Nadkarni's former grad student, Jade Blackwater, who then said, in China the number is 900 billion.
Which is about 25 million trees in equivalence.
Nalini, Jade, and a team of students created a list of tree-based products.
It's a long list.
Baby cribs and baseball bats.
Barrels and landscaping bark.
Nail polish.
Luggage, magazines.
Party invitations, particle board.
Toilet paper, toothpaste, turpentine.
Ping-pong balls.
Beds, billboards, birthday cards.
Fireworks.
Ms.
BLACKWATER and Dr. NADKARNI: Bulletin boards, tambourines, telephone books, umbrella handles, vacuum cornish, vitamins, xylophones and yo-yos.
Yo-yos?
Wooden yo-yos.
Oh yes.
The point is there are so many tree-based products, there is no way to know how much tree any of us use every year.
You could guess.
My guess is that we are using more than our 61 trees because, actually, the cover of trees is decreasing over the surface of the Earth.
And obviously, some of us consume more.
Americans, for example, use 27 times more paper than Indians.
But Nalini says this is not one of those, oh, I'm a bad, bad person stories.
I don't want people to feel guilty about their relationships with trees and say, oh, my God, I can never touch another tree-created product again.
We invited two contemporary artists, African-American women from very different backgrounds, to share their thoughts on this American anthem.
Because, she says, remember, trees are not like oil.
Trees are renewable.
So if you think you're using more than your 61, the obvious solution is plant a few more.
So, yeah, we may be consuming a lot...
I would assume that we're the gobblers.
But gobblers, she says, can be planters too.
Robert Krulwich, NPR News.
This is Morning Edition from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Rescue workers have found the equivalent of a small town in Galveston, Texas.
By yesterday afternoon, nearly 2,000 people had been taken off the island and bused to shelters after surviving Hurricane Ike.
In Houston, nearly 2 million people remain without power, and that was only one frustration for that city's residents.
They also complained of not enough shelters and no sites to pick up food or water.
Essentially, they say they're not getting enough help from local and federal officials.
And our coverage begins with NPR's Carrie Kahn in Houston.
Houston residents emerged from their hot and powerless homes searching for water, ice and gasoline.
Federal officials had said that after Ike had passed, 5 million liters of water, and millions of ready-to-eat meals, stockpiled in northern Texas were on the way.
But by the time Homeland Security Director Michael Chertoff faced reporters late yesterday afternoon in Houston, the trucks had yet to arrive.
And that put him on the defensive.
I'm going to try to put it into - this is not about a screw-up.

Mindful of public outrage over the slow federal response following Hurricane Katrina, Chertoff stressed that it had been just 24 hours since weather conditions were safe enough for 18-wheelers to move into the city.
And he added that it wasn't until early Sunday morning that FEMA was asked to actually assume the duty of handing out supplies to weary Houstonians.
This is a shared responsibility.
We all play a role in this.
We all wind up backfilling sometimes if an unanticipated problem comes up.
And I think that's the spirit in which we're going at this thing.

Two Houston-area congressmen complained about the delays in getting the FEMA supplies to residents, and Republican Congressman John Culberson blasted federal officials for leaving emergency personnel at two staging areas without food and water.
Houston Mayor Bill White says he wasn't even informed that FEMA was taking over food and water distribution.
For now, he says, he's willing to wait and see whether FEMA can do it.
If they won't do it, we'll find somebody to supplement what FEMA can do to get the supplies here.
By nightfall, semi trucks were moving out of Houston's Reliant Park toward five distribution points set up throughout the greater Houston area.
Guards at the gate would not say where the trucks were going or what was inside.
For his part, Texas Governor Rick Perry refrained from specifically criticizing FEMA.
But on several occasions yesterday, Perry did make a point of saying that he hopes Texans get the same level of federal support that Louisianans received after Hurricane Katrina.
